Skilling becomes CEO while Lay stays on as chairman.
Skilling resigns and Lay becomes CEO again.
Enron announces a third-quarter loss of $618 million.
The company later reveals that it overstated earnings dating back to 1997.
The company discloses that it is under formal investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Enron confirms that it has agreed to be purchased by a rival company, Dynegy for $9 billion.
Dynegy announces it has terminated merger talks with Enron.
Enron files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
The US Department of Justice opens a criminal investigation into Enron's collapse.
Arthur Andersen LLP, the accounting firm that handled Enron's audits, discloses that its employees had destroyed company documents.
The New York Stock Exchange suspends trading of Enron shares.
Enron ends its partnership with Arthur Andersen
Lay resigns as CEO.
He later steps down from the board of directors.
Former Enron vice chairman J. Clifford Baxter is found dead in an apparent suicide.
Lay invokes his Fifth Amendment right before the Senate Commerce Committee.
The DOJ indicts Arthur Andersen for obstruction of justice.
A jury later returns a guilty verdict for the accounting firm.
The Supreme Court later overturns the conviction.
Skilling is charged with 35 counts of fraud and insider trading.
Lay is indicted.
He is charged with conspiracy, securities fraud, wire fraud, bank fraud and making false statements.
During his arraignment the next day, he pleads not guilty to all 11 charges and is released on $500,000 unsecured bond.
Skilling and Lay are convicted of conspiracy and fraud.
Lay dies of a heart attack while awaiting sentencing.
A class action lawsuit filed by shareholders and investors is settled in federal court.
Skilling files a petition with the Supreme Court to overturn his conviction after appeals with the lower courts fail.
"Enron," a Broadway musical about the company's collapse, closes on Broadway 12 days after opening amid slow ticket sales.
The Supreme Court rejects Skilling's appeal.
A federal judge reduces Skilling's sentence by more than 10 years.
In return, Skilling agrees to stop challenging his conviction and forfeit roughly $42 million that will be distributed among the victims of the Enron fraud.
The SEC announces that it has obtained a summary judgment against Skilling,
